properties.title: App Service LZA - Secure Baseline multitenant

body.query: ResourceContainers | where type =~ 'microsoft.resources/subscriptions' | where properties.state =~ 'enabled' | project label=tostring(name), description=subscriptionId, value=subscriptionId | order by label asc

elements.name: workloadName
elements.label: Workload Name
elements.toolTip: suffix (max 10 characters long) that will be used to name the resources in a pattern like <resourceAbbreviation>-<workloadName>

validations.message: The value must have a length of at most 10.

elements.name: environmentName
elements.label: Environment Name
elements.toolTip: Required. The name of the Environment Name (e.g. "dev", "test", "prod", "preprod", "staging", "uat", "dr", "qa"). Up to 8 characters long.

validations.message: The value must have a length of at most 8.

options.text: Select one of the predefined SKUs for your App Service Plan, and the desired underlying OS (Linux or Windows). If you wish to deploy a Zone Redundant App Service, select one of the SKUs with the suffix _AZ.

elements.name: webAppPlanSku
elements.label: Web App Plan Sku
elements.toolTip: Defines the name, tier, size, family and capacity of the App Service Plan. Plans ending to _AZ, are deplying at least three instances in three Availability Zones. EP* is only for functions

elements.name: webAppBaseOs
elements.label: Web App Base Os
elements.toolTip: Kind of server OS of the App Service Plan

elements.name: sectionHubSelector
elements.label: Create a new Hub or use an existing one?

options.text: Do you want to deploy a new Hub (with all the necessary resources, i.e. Virtual Network, Azure Firewall, Azure Bastion etc), or do you prefer use an existing one? The existing hub must be in the same region, and have Azure Firewall, and Azure Bastion deployed in it.

link.label: More info for the Hub resources, at the Architecture Diagram

elements.name: deployHub
elements.label: Deploy a new Hub, or use an existing one?

elements.name: sectionHubNew
elements.label: CIDR Settings for new Hub network and subnets

options.text: You can accept the default address spaces, as shown below, or you can use your own.

link.label: What address ranges can I use in my Virtual Networks?

elements.name: vnetHubAddressSpace
elements.label: Hub Virtual Network Address Space
elements.toolTip: CIDR of the HUB vnet i.e. 192.168.0.0/24 - optional if you want to use an existing hub vnet (vnetHubResourceId)

validations.message: Invalid CIDR range. The address prefix must be in the range [10,24].

elements.name: subnetHubFirewallAddressSpace
elements.label: Hub Subnet CIDR for Azure Firewall
elements.toolTip: CIDR of the subnet hosting the azure Firewall - optional if you want to use an existing hub vnet (vnetHubResourceId)

validations.message: Invalid CIDR range. The address prefix must be in the range [20,26].

elements.name: subnetHubBastionAddressSpace
elements.label: Hub Subnet CIDR for Bastion Service
elements.toolTip: CIDR of the subnet hosting the Bastion Service - optional if you want to use an existing hub vnet (vnetHubResourceId)

validations.message: Invalid CIDR range. The address prefix must be in the range [20,26].

elements.name: sectionHubExisting
elements.label: Information for the existing Hub resources

elements.name: vnetHubResourceId
elements.label: Hub Vnet Resource Id
elements.toolTip: Default is empty. If empty, then a new hub will be created. If given, no new hub will be created and we create the  peering between spoke and and existing hub vnet

elements.name: firewallInternalIp
elements.label: Firewall Internal IP
elements.toolTip: Internal IP of the Azure firewall deployed in Hub. Used for creating UDR to route all vnet egress traffic through Firewall. If empty no UDR

elements.name: sectionSpoke
elements.label: CIDR Settings for the Spoke network and subnets

options.text: You can accept the default address spaces, as shown below, or you can use your own.

link.label: What address ranges can I use in my Virtual Networks?

elements.name: vnetSpokeAddressSpace
elements.label: Spoke Virtual Network Address Space
elements.toolTip: CIDR of the SPOKE vnet i.e. 192.168.0.0/24

validations.message: Invalid CIDR range. The address prefix must be in the range [10,24].

elements.name: subnetSpokeAppSvcAddressSpace
elements.label: Spoke Subnet CIDR for Azure App Service
elements.toolTip: CIDR of the subnet that will hold the app services plan

validations.message: Invalid CIDR range. The address prefix must be in the range [20,26].

elements.name: subnetSpokeDevOpsAddressSpace
elements.label: Spoke Subnet CIDR for Dev Ops agent (VM)
elements.toolTip: CIDR of the subnet that will hold devOps agents etc

validations.message: Invalid CIDR range. The address prefix must be in the range [20,26].

elements.name: subnetSpokePrivateEndpointAddressSpace
elements.label: Spoke Subnet CIDR for Azure Private Endpoints
elements.toolTip: CIDR of the subnet that will hold the private endpoints of the supporting services

validations.message: Invalid CIDR range. The address prefix must be in the range [20,26].

elements.name: location
elements.label: Location
elements.toolTip: Azure region where the resources will be deployed in

elements.name: numericSuffix
elements.label: Numeric Suffix
elements.toolTip: Optional. A numeric suffix (e.g. "001") to be appended on the naming generated for the resources. Defaults to empty.

elements.name: deployJumpHost
elements.label: Deploy Jump Box?
elements.toolTip: set to true if you want to deploy a jumpbox/devops VM

options.text: Give the CredentialsCombo for your windows Jump-box. The VM will be AAD Joined, so you can use your AAD credentials to login. The password must contain at least 12 characters, with at least 1 uppercase, 1 lowercase and 1 number.

link.label: Learn more for Windows VM Password Policy

constraints.validationMessage: Only alphanumeric characters are allowed, and the value must be 8-15 characters long.

constraints.customValidationMessage: The password must contain at least 12 characters, with at least 1 uppercase, 1 lowercase and 1 number.

options.text: Below you can select if you wish to deploy some additional tools on the jump-box VM, i.e. azure cli, azure developer cli, git, sql server management studio. Have in mind that the more the tools you select, the more time it will take for the deployment to complete.

elements.name: deployClis
elements.label: Install useful CLIs (Azure, AZD, and Git)?
elements.toolTip: set to true if you want to install CLIs on the jump-box VM

elements.name: deploySsms
elements.label: install Sql Server Management Studio (SSMS)?
elements.toolTip: set to true if you want install Sql Server Management Studio (SSMS) on the jump-box VM

elements.name: deployGitHubRunner
elements.label: Install Github Runner?
elements.toolTip: set to true if you want to deploy selft hosted GitHub Actions runner

elements.name: githubRepositoryUrl
elements.label: GitHub Repository URL
elements.toolTip: The URL of the Github repository to use for the Github Actions Runner. If this parameter is provided, then github_token must also be provided.

elements.name: githubToken
elements.label: GitHub Token
elements.toolTip: The GitHub token to use for the Github Actions Runner. If this parameter is provided, then github_repository_url must also be provided.

elements.name: jumpBoxAzDoAgentSection
elements.label: Azure DevOps Self Hosted Agent Settings

elements.name: deployAzDoSelfHostedAgent
elements.label: Install Azure DevOps Self Hosted Agent?
elements.toolTip: set to true if you want to deploy self hosted agent for Azure DevOps

elements.name: adoOrganization
elements.label: URL of the Azure DevOps organization
elements.toolTip: The URL of the Azure DevOps organization to use for the Azure DevOps Agent. If this parameter is provided, then ado_token must also be provided

elements.name: adoToken
elements.label: Azure DevOps Token
elements.toolTip: The Azure DevOps token to use for the Azure DevOps Agent. If this parameter is provided, then ado_organization must also be provided.

elements.name: sqlServerIntroSection
elements.label: Azure SQL Server deployment feature flag

options.text: Select if you wish to deploy an Azure SQL Server with a default database. This will require more time in the deployment.

elements.name: deployAzureSql
elements.label: Deploy Azure Sql Server?
elements.toolTip: Set to true if you want to deploy a azure SQL server and default database

options.text: Select the authentication method for the SQL Server administrator. Azure AD for SQL Server administrator authentication is suggested.

elements.name: azureSqlAuthentication
elements.label: Azure Sql Server Authentication
elements.toolTip: Select Azure AD for SQL Server administrator authentication for better security and passwordless access. If you select SQL Server local user, you will need to provide a password for the SQL Server administrator.

options.text: Replace AAD_SQL_ADMIN_GROUP with Azure AD group where your Azure administrators are members, sid value (xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx) with Azure AD object ID of that group. The current tenantId value is already filled in.

elements.name: sqlServerAdministrators
elements.label: Sql Server Administrators
elements.toolTip: Replace AAD_SQL_ADMIN_GROUP with Azure AD group where your Azure administrators are members, sid value with Azure AD object ID of that group and tenantId value with Azure AD tenant ID where the group is located

elements.name: sqlAdminLogin
elements.label: Sql Admin Login
elements.toolTip: Conditional. If sqlServerAdministrators is given, this is not required.

elements.name: sqlAdminPassword
elements.toolTip: Conditional. If sqlServerAdministrators is given, this is not required -check password policy: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/security/password-policy?view=azuresqldb-current

elements.name: enableEgressLockdown
elements.label: Enable Egress Lockdown
elements.toolTip: set to true if you want to intercept all outbound traffic with azure firewall

elements.name: deployRedis
elements.label: Deploy Redis
elements.toolTip: set to true if you want to a redis cache

elements.name: deployAppConfig
elements.label: Deploy App Config
elements.toolTip: set to true if you want to deploy application configuration

elements.name: autoApproveAfdPrivateEndpoint
elements.label: Auto Approve Afd Private Endpoint
elements.toolTip: set to true if you want to auto approve the Private Endpoint of the AFD
